awd_titl_txt: Combustion studies of high water content fuels
awd_abstract_narration:
1337008
Axebaum

Biomass holds great potential as a fuel as it addresses two important issues ? global climate change and the demand for renewable fuels.  Biomass generally has high moisture content and is usually dried before being utilized.  Nonetheless, there are a number of applications where ?wet? biomass can be useful.  For example, when biomass is burned with oxygen in a power plant and the resulting carbon dioxide is stored underground, the process leads to carbon negative power production. 

This program seeks to gain knowledge of the physico-chemical processes associated with combustion of high-moisture content fuels.  Three types of biomass/water mixtures will be studied: alcohol/water solutions, algal suspensions, and biomass solubilized in water. The vaporization and combustion characteristics will be studied in single droplet experiments and in a spray combustor. Analytical models of two-component droplet vaporization and combustion will be used to understand and interpret results.

This work will provide fundamental data needed to support technologies for a sustainable approach to power generation with carbon capture and storage. The research will be an important educational tool, exposing our youth to novel approaches to renewable, sustainable technologies. In addition, an innovative, interdisciplinary experiential course on Energy and Environment will be developed.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Concerns over emissions of CO2 from fossil fuel combustion have prompted interest in alternative fuels and in developing carbon neutral or carbon negative processes to supply electricity. Biomass is a promising alternative for renewable fuels. However, it generally contains a very high water content. For example, the broth in the production of bioethanol contains over 90% water. In the growth of microalgae, the water content in the culture is above 99%. Normally, energy intensive dewatering processes are needed before the raw material can be used to produce energy.

To avoid the dewatering process and maximize the energy efficiency of the process, a new approach was developed – direct combustion of high-water-content fuels, or wet fuels. This concept not only avoids energy intensive dewatering steps, but it could also achieve a higher energy efficiency than traditional processes. By replacing the two-step method for generating steam, which involves a combustor and a boiler, with a single-step method where the wet fuel is burned directly in an oxygen-enriched environment, a flue gas comprised mostly of high temperature steam can be generated, which can then be used to drive a turbine.

The outcomes of this project are summarized as follows:

It was demonstrated that it is possible to obtain a stable flame for ethanol/water mixtures with as little as 10% ethanol when burned in pure oxygen, and as little as 25% when burned in air. It was determined that the strong preferential vaporization of ethanol over water is the main reason why it is possible to obtain robust flames in a system which should otherwise be unignitable.

The concept of preferential vaporization was studied in detail. When an alcohol is mixed with water, a non-ideal solution is formed. The activity coefficient of a mixture describes the extent of its departure from an ideal solution. The activity coefficient of alcohol in water increases with water fraction and can be as high as 5 for a mixture of 10% ethanol/90% water. This means that the ethanol in the mixture will vaporize five times faster than what would be expected based on its concentration in the mixture. Thus, the increase in activity coefficient offsets the reduction in fuel concentration, which allows for stable combustion of dilute ethanol/water mixtures.

In the case of fuels with low volatility relative to water, the opposite behavior occurs - the water vaporizes preferentially over the fuel. Stable glycerol/water flames required at least 60% glycerol to burn in pure oxygen but, even then, the flame is lifted from the nozzle. To enhance the stability of the glycerol/water mixtures, a high volatility fuel (ethanol) was added, allowing attached, robust flames to be obtained for 30% glycerol/10% ethanol/60% water mixtures.

To better understand why adding ethanol to glycerol/water mixtures improves flame stability, the spray breakup and structure of glycerol/water and glycerol/ethanol/water mixtures were investigated. Apart from ethanol's strong preferential vaporization, it was also found that the addition of ethanol affects the spray breakup and dynamics, leading to an initial concentration of fine droplets in the critical region of the spray, right above the nozzle, which allows the ethanol in the mixture to evaporate rapidly in the vicinity of the nozzle that is critical for ignition, allowing for strong, stable flames.

The results obtained in this project are important in several ways:

The fundamental knowledge gained on 1) how non-ideal mixtures affect preferential vaporization for multi-component fuels, and 2) how the composition of a fuel can affect spray breakup and dynamics, will be useful for studies and applications of combustion of multicomponent fuels. Since there is currently much interest in using mixtures of conventional fuels with biofuels for energy generation and for transportation, a better understanding of how changing fuel composition affects the combustion process is needed before biofuel mixtures can be widely utilized. 

This research also demonstrated a potentially low-cost method of utilizing renewable fuels by eliminating the energy intensive dewatering process. The method developed has potential applications anywhere where a stream of high temperature steam is required, such as in enhanced oil recovery, and also for power generation.

This project also identified another major area where the methods developed show great potential: spray pyrolysis for the synthesis of cathode materials for Li-ion batteries. Spray pyrolysis is a scalable process for the manufacturing of nanostructured materials with significant advantages over other methods, including synthesis of high purity and reproducible materials with minimal wastewater production. While spray pyrolysis has been shown to address many of the criteria for successful production of nanostructured cathode materials, morphological control presents a major challenge. By utilizing wet fuels for spray pyrolysis, it is possible to fine tune the temperature history that  the material experiences, improving control over the morphology of the final product.



Last Modified: 12/01/2016
Modified by: Richard L Axelbaum
